item.title: Animal Crossing: New Horizons Guides Hub
item.content:encoded:
GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

Animal Crossing: New Horizons, originally released in March 2020, remains a beloved Nintendo classic today. With the Animal Crossing: New Horizons 3.0 update, the game has reclaimed the spotlight. Whether you're new to the game, coming back for the 3.0 update, or someone who has never stopped playing it, our New Horizons guides hub is a one-stop shop to help you beautify your island, complete all collections in the game, upgrade everything, and live the Animal Crossing life you've dreamed of.

We've split the guides into several categories, which you can browse below to find exactly what you need, whether it's helpful starter tips, details surrounding timed seasonal events, or knowing how to spot the Jolly Redd real or fake art pieces, and more.

Table of Contents [hide]

  • Starter tips
  • Special items and features
  • Major locations
  • Villagers and visitors
  • Collections
    • Limited-time fish and bugs
  • Seasonal events
    • DIY recipes

Starter tips

These guides are designed to help you get up to speed with the early parts of the game, for both newcomers and long-timers who need a refresher. Included right at the top is a guide on how to move your Animal Crossing: New Horizons island to Switch 2.

  • Island transfer tool: Transfer your save to Switch 2
  • Starter guide
  • First-day checklist
  • How to make money fast
  • Island designer
  • How to get a shovel
  • How to get a ladder
  • How to swim
  • Increase inventory size
  • Add friends
  • Introduction to Summer 2020 update
  • Introduction to 2.0 (November 2021)

Special items and features

Animal Crossing: New Horizons is built on the series' past mechanics and introduces a lot of new elements, too. These guides help you with quick how-to subjects for when you brush up against the game's more intricate parts and special items.

  • Make custom designs
  • Automated island cleaning
  • Permanent ladders
  • Ordinances
  • Pumpkins
  • Fireworks
  • Shrubs
  • Hybrid flowers
  • Turnips
  • Pearls
  • Dreams
  • Gulliver's communication parts

Major locations

However your island looks, there will be many sights to see--and even build yourself. These are our guides to those places of interest.

  • Nook's Cranny upgrades
  • Museum unlock and upgrades
  • Able Sisters unlock and upgrades
  • Campsite
  • Resident services
  • Harv's Island
  • Deserted island
  • Tarantula Island

Villagers and visitors

A town would merely be a collection of buildings if not for your neighbors and friends. These guides help you learn about the friendly faces that may live next door, as well as those who visit every so often.

  • Brewster
  • Flick
  • Kicks
  • Redd's art: Real or fake?
  • Pascal
  • Pirate Gulliver
  • CJ
  • Sanrio villagers

Collections

Whether it's fish, bugs, or even K.K. Slider songs, Animal Crossing: New Horizons is full of things to collect. Here's how to fill out your collections.

  • Bugs
    • Wasps
    • Fleas
    • Flies
    • Ants
    • Snails
    • Mole crickets
    • Scorpions
  • Fish
    • Coelacanth
    • Summer 2020 sea creatures update
  • K.K. Slider songs

Limited-time fish and bugs

Some fish and bugs only come around in certain times of year, since the game features a real-world clock and calendar. If you need these seasonal critters, here's when to look for them.

  • January fish and bugs
  • February fish and bugs
  • March last-chance fish and bugs
  • April fish and bugs
    • April last-chance fish and bugs
  • May fish and bugs
    • May last chance fish and bugs
  • June fish and bugs
  • July fish and bugs
  • September fish and bugs
    • September last-chance fish and bugs
  • October fish and bugs

Seasonal events

Perhaps the game's most beloved aspect is its calendar of limited-time events. From fishing tournaments to Bunny Day, here's what to know about each in-game celebration.

  • Festivale
  • Bunny Day
  • May Day Maze
  • Museum Day Stamp Rally
  • Fishing Tournament
  • Bug-Off

DIY recipes

Lots of new cosmetic items come to the game at different times of the year, usually alongside events. These guides will help you decorate for various events and seasons.

  • Festive DIY recipes
  • Snowflake DIY recipes
  • Snowboy DIY recipes
  • Cherry blossom DIY recipes
  • Balloon DIY recipes
  • Acorn and pinecone DIY recipes
  • Pumpkin and spooky set DIY recipes
  • Bunny Day DIY recipes
  • Summer Shells DIY recipes

Got a news tip or want to contact us directly? Email news@gamespot.com

item.title: Rockstar's Battle With Union Over Fired Devs Goes To Court
item.content:encoded:
GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

Near the end of October 2025, Rockstar fired over thirty devs in the United Kingdom and Canada over what it called "gross misconduct." The Independent Workers' Union of Great Britain accused Rockstar of union busting for laying off workers who were organizing with the union. Both sides have held firm since the initial accusations, and now the battle has gone to court in the UK.

As reported by Video Games Chronicle, Rockstar and the IWGB went before the court earlier this week, where the latter requested that the fired workers be given "interim relief" while the legal drama plays out. If granted, that would place the affected workers back on Rockstar's payroll and allow some to keep their visas that were reliant on their jobs. The court will reportedly decide on the matter before the end of the week.

The IWGB pledged to continue fighting for the workers regardless of the court's decision, while Rockstar reiterated its position that the workers broke the company's policy.

"We have consistently made clear that we took necessary action against a group of individuals across the UK and Canada who discussed highly confidential information, including relating to game features from upcoming and unannounced titles, in an insecure and public social channel," a Rockstar spokesperson told IGN. "This was a breach of long-standing and well-understood confidentiality policies. This channel contained at least 25 non-Rockstar employees, including employees of competitor game developers, a video games industry journalist, as well as dozens of anonymous, unidentifiable members. Meanwhile, employees who posted union-supportive messages, but who did not breach confidentiality policies, were not dismissed."

There is some question as to whether the alleged break of confidentiality had anything to do with Grand Theft Auto 6. A report from November 2025 noted that the employees in question shared details about Rockstar's rule changes for Slack, which eliminated most of the personal and non-work channels. That story also stated that Rockstar's internal security is so tight that employees can't even check their work emails unless they are in the office.

This case may boil down to whether Rockstar can prove that the employees shared sensitive details that violated their terms of employment. The case has drawn a considerable amount of attention worldwide. UK Prime Minister Keir Starmer and MP Chris Murray have both pledged to look into it, but the legal battle may take a long time to play out.

Got a news tip or want to contact us directly? Email news@gamespot.com



https://www.gamespot.com/articles/rockstars-battle-with-union-over-fired-devs-goes-to-court/1100-6537286/?ftag=CAD-01-10abi2f
